user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAccept_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAccept_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *sock_token, const OS_object_token_t *conn_token,
                           OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    uint32                          operation;
    socklen_t                       addrlen;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *sock_impl;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;

    sock_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *sock_token);
    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *conn_token);

    operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE;
    if (sock_impl->selectable)
    {
        return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(sock_token, &operation, timeout);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if ((operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE) == 0)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
        }
        else
        {
            addrlen       = Addr->ActualLength;
            conn_impl->fd = accept(sock_impl->fd, (struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData, &addrlen);
            if (conn_impl->fd < 0)
            {
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                Addr->ActualLength = addrlen;

                OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS(conn_token);
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAccept_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
#define OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS(tok) OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(tok)
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT (-4)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed the provided function and related definitions for use of compiler-specific language extensions. The code does not use any of the common compiler extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (for example: __attribute__ or __declspec, __asm, statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, nested functions, labels-as-values, asm volatile, __builtin_* intrinsics, GNU/Clang __extension__ markers, or nonstandard keyword variants). The following items were specifically checked and found to be standard C features, not compiler extensions in this codebase:

- Use of static inline for OS_ObjectIndexFromToken and other inline definitions — this is standard C (C99 and later). 
- Use of typedefs like int32, uint32, size_t, socklen_t and bool — these are standard types or typical typedefs provided by standard headers/OSAL, not compiler extensions. 
- Macros (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS) use purely standard preprocessor constructs. The address-of usage in the macro (&(tok)) is valid C when the macro argument is an lvalue (as in the calls shown) and is not a language extension. 
- Use of system calls and library functions (accept, fcntl, strerror, errno) are POSIX/standard library calls, not compiler language extensions. 
- Comment annotations (/**< ... */) are Doxygen-style comments, not language extensions.

Given this, there are no code fragments in the supplied code that should be flagged for potential MISRA Rule 1.2 violations related to compiler language extensions.
